It has been established that the transformation proceeds in the same manner for both catalyst types, via dehydrogenationjhydrogen transfer and dehydration reaction steps. Introduction It was reported in 1976 by Ja_3anese researchers [1] that in the presence of RhC13/PPh3 catalyst 1,3-di:-3Is with various structures are converted to oxo compounds. They did not undertake investigations with regard to the mechanism of the transformation, but merely stated that the 4-hydroxy-2pentanone detected in the case of the reaction of 2,4-pentanediol might play a rcle in the oxe compound formation. In our own earlier examinations in which we studied the vapour-phase, heterogeneous catalytic transformations of 1,3-dioLs in the presence of metals, and primarily various copper catalysts [2) , we similarly established that oxo compound formatio-n is the main reaction for certain diols. The results of work with 1,3-butanediol-[3 2Hj , aimed at clarification of the mechanism, demonstrated that the transformation is a several-step process (dehydrogenation, dehydration, hydrogen transfer) requiring the participation of two intermediates, namely, a f3-hydroxy-0xo compound and an a, aunsaturaO oxo compound E3) . In the light of the above experimental facts, we set out: (a) to establish the mechanism of oxo compound formation under homogeneous conditions; (b) to study ogo compound formation in the presence of heterogeneous rhodiuO catalysts, and to compare the results obtained with the observations made with copper catalysts; 226 (c) t-) make a cc _:iparison between the mechanisms f olding for homogeneous, arid =ieterogenen-is rhodium catalysts. Gas chromatographic analysis was performed on samples taken from the reaction mixture, and for identification the substances formed were distilled from the reaction mixture. This lower selectivity can be attributed to the fact that the intermediate (3-hydroxy-oxo compound can undergo further transformation, not only by dehydration, but also by retroaldol reaction, with the formation of two further oxo compounds The elecirophilic and nucleophilic centres of the catalysts play a-L essential role in the retroaldol reactions [4, 5) , and, since both of the catalysts u.=ed possess such centres [5] , it is understandable that the quantity of product,: so formed will be relatively higher. The same effect results from the fact that the rhodium catalysts have a low metal content, and, thus, the interactions of the supports can be manifested more strongly. A higher reaction temperature also produces a similar result. Otherwise, some chaiacteristic observations (the almost identical product distribution, the identified intermediate methyl vinyl ketone, and the hyarogenatinw-dehydrogenating ability of the metal catalysts) permit the conclusion that the oxo compound is formed on these rhodium catalysts by the mechanism proved earlier [3) . These experimental data unambiguously indicate that in the presence of the RhC13/PPh3 catalyst the traAnnsformation of the 1,3-diols to monoketones with the same number of carbon atoms commences with the formation of the ss-hydroxy -oxo compound. Under acidic conditions, this gives rise to an unsaturated ketone, which is hydrogenated by the Rh(P)-H catalyst species. Oar current investigations have the aim of establishing the structure of the active catalyst species. Conclusions By studying the dehydration of 1,3-iiols to ogo compounds by the action of different heterogeneous and homogeneous rhodium catalysts, we have revealed that the process takes place via the formation of the same intermediates on both catalysts (Scheme 2). The dehydrogenation/hydrogen transfer step is catalyzed by the metal in both cases: in the heterogeneous vapour-ph2se transformation the process occurs by the action. of the metallic rhodium, while in the homogeneous reaction a rhodiuni--phosphine complex 231 -CH--CH2 I __H OH OH - -C-CH=CH- a 0 -H20 -C--CH? -CH O OH -~-eH2-.OH2 O Scheme 2. is the active species. In the high-tempera,ure heterogeneous transformation the intermediate g-hydroxy-oxo compound undergoes dehydration in a thermal process or by the action of the electrophilic centres of the catalyst, while in the homogeneous phase the formation of the a , (3-unsaturated oxo compound is induced by the Bronsted acid produced in the reaction. The oxo compound is formed with much higher selectivity with the homogeneous catalyst; at the high temperature employed under the heterogeneous conditions, the p-hydroxy-oxo compound may be transformed in other reactions besides dehydration, and the oxo compounds formed may also be reduced to alcohols.
